head.title: British Court Names Terror Case Escapee

hedline.hl1: British Court Names Terror Case Escapee
hedline.hl2: British Court Names Terror Case Escapee

abstract.p: British court lifts restriction on identifying terrorism suspect who escaped from mental hospital last year and remains at large; he is Zeeshan Siddiqui, who is accused of having met other militants in Britain and Pakistan (S)

block.p: A British court lifted restrictions Thursday on identifying a terrorism suspect who was said to have absconded last year by clambering through a window at a mental hospital. He is still at large.
The suspect, Zeeshan Siddiqui, 26, a former worker on the London subway system, is accused of having met other militants in Britain and Pakistan.

A British court lifted restrictions Thursday on identifying a terrorism suspect who was said to have absconded last year by clambering through a window at a mental hospital. He is still at large.
The suspect, Zeeshan Siddiqui, 26, a former worker on the London subway system, is accused of having met other militants in Britain and Pakistan.

Last month, the names of three men who also disappeared while under official restrictions were made public. The restrictions, which fall short of formal imprisonment, limit the movements of suspects who have not been convicted of crimes under Britain's counterterrorism laws.
Mr. Siddiqui's name came to prominence in 2005 when extracts of a diary he had written were published in The New York Times.
